newsitem.title: USA: Microsoft to phase out NT development for PowerPC.
newsitem.headline: Microsoft to phase out NT development for PowerPC.

text.p: Microsoft Corp Friday said that it plans to phase out its development of its Windows NT operating system on the PowerPC architecture, in response to decreasing demand for PowerPC systems.
Microsoft said it plans to continue offering technical support to its customers who use Windows NT 4.0 on the PowerPC architecture.

In December, International Business Machines Corp said it and its partners would discontinue development for that system. The PowerPC chip was developed by IBM with Motorola Inc and Apple Computer Inc.

At that time, Microsoft could not be reached for comment. Then, analysts said that IBM intended to focus on its workstation business that runs the UNIX operating system on its PowerPC technology, and that the PowerPC-based systems running Windows NT were not very successful for IBM.
In the early 1990s, PowerPC was seen as the strongest alternative to Intel Corp's dominance of the computer microprocessor market.
Microsoft said it plans to continue working closely with Motorola to enhance PowerPC solutions for non-PC devices.
